**Bone Thugs-N-Harmony** is an American [hip hop](/wiki/Hip_hop_music "Hip hop
music") group. It consists of [rappers](/wiki/Rapper "Rapper") [Bizzy
Bone](/wiki/Bizzy_Bone "Bizzy Bone"), [Wish Bone](/wiki/Wish_Bone "Wish
Bone"), [Layzie Bone](/wiki/Layzie_Bone "Layzie Bone"), [Krayzie
Bone](/wiki/Krayzie_Bone "Krayzie Bone"), and [Flesh-n-Bone](/wiki/Flesh-n-
Bone "Flesh-n-Bone"). American [West Coast rapper](/wiki/West_Coast_rap "West
Coast rap") [Eazy-E](/wiki/Eazy-E "Eazy-E") signed Bone Thugs-N-Harmony to
[Ruthless Records](/wiki/Ruthless_Records "Ruthless Records") in late 1993,
when Bone Thugs debuted with their [EP](/wiki/Extended_play "Extended play")
_[Creepin on ah Come Up](/wiki/Creepin_on_ah_Come_Up "Creepin on ah Come
Up")_. The EP included their breakout hit single "[Thuggish Ruggish
Bone](/wiki/Thuggish_Ruggish_Bone "Thuggish Ruggish Bone")".

In 1995, the group released its second album, _[E. 1999
Eternal](/wiki/E._1999_Eternal "E. 1999 Eternal")_ , which included hits "[1st
of tha Month](/wiki/1st_of_tha_Month "1st of tha Month")" and "[East
1999](/wiki/East_1999 "East 1999")". A tribute to then-recently deceased
Eazy-E, titled "[Tha Crossroads](/wiki/Tha_Crossroads "Tha Crossroads")", won
a [Grammy award](/wiki/Grammy_award "Grammy award") in 1997. _[The Art of
War](/wiki/The_Art_of_War_\(Bone_Thugs-n-Harmony_album\) "The Art of War
\(Bone Thugs-n-Harmony album\)")_ , the group's third album, was also released
in 1997. Bone Thugs is the only group that has worked with [2Pac](/wiki/2Pac
"2Pac"), [Notorious B.I.G.](/wiki/Notorious_B.I.G. "Notorious B.I.G."),
[Eazy-E](/wiki/Eazy-E "Eazy-E"), and [Big Pun](/wiki/Big_Pun "Big Pun") while
they were still alive. The editors of [About.com](/wiki/About.com "About.com")
ranked them #12 on their list of the "25 Best Rap Groups of All Time",[3] and
[MTV](/wiki/MTV "MTV") called them "the most melodic hip-hop group of all
time".[4]

In 2000, _[BTNHResurrection](/wiki/BTNHResurrection "BTNHResurrection")_
reached [platinum](/wiki/Platinum_disc "Platinum disc") in one month, while
2002's _[Thug World Order](/wiki/Thug_World_Order "Thug World Order")_
received more moderate sales and promotion, going [gold](/wiki/Gold_disc "Gold
disc") and peaking at #3 on the [Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums](/wiki/Top_R%26B/Hip-
Hop_Albums "Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums") chart. After that album, the group went
on hiatus from their label and released their sixth studio album, _[Thug
Stories](/wiki/Thug_Stories "Thug Stories")_ , independently in 2006. In 2007
they had another major-label release, _[Strength&
Loyalty](/wiki/Strength_%26_Loyalty "Strength & Loyalty")_, on [Swizz
Beatz](/wiki/Swizz_Beatz "Swizz Beatz")'s label [Full Surface
Records](/wiki/Full_Surface_Records "Full Surface Records"). Bone Thugs-N-
Harmony "officially" returned with their 2010 album _[Uni5: The World's
Enemy](/wiki/Uni5:_The_World%27s_Enemy "Uni5: The World's Enemy")_, released
by their own record label, [BTNH Worldwide](/wiki/BTNH_Worldwide "BTNH
Worldwide"), with distribution by [Warner Bros.](/wiki/Warner_Bros._Records
"Warner Bros. Records")

Due to conflicts within the group, longtime members Krayzie Bone and Wish Bone
officially left the group in April 2011 to work with their independent label,
The Life Entertainment.[5][6][7] They would later return, officially re-
unifying the group. In August 2013, however, Layzie Bone announced that _he_
would be stepping aside to work more on his solo career.[8][9] In the same
month, BTNH signed with eOne Entertainment (formerly known as [Koch
Records](/wiki/Koch_Records "Koch Records")), who they had previously
partnered with to release 2006's _Thug Stories_.[10] Layzie Bone has since re-
united with the group. On April 28th the entire group performed a show in
Biloxi, MS along with Juvenile & Nelly. On June 1st of 2018, Bone Thugs will
be reuniting for a show just outside Boston, Massachusetts, at the Wonderland
Ballroom in Revere, MA.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bone_Thugs-n-
Harmony&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")]

### 1991–93: B.O.N.E. Enterprise early
years[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bone_Thugs-n-Harmony&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: 1991–93: B.O.N.E. Enterprise early years")]

Formed in [Cleveland, Ohio](/wiki/Cleveland,_Ohio "Cleveland, Ohio") in
1991,[1][2] the group was originally called "The Band-Aid Boys". They then
formed B.O.N.E. Enterpri$e, which consisted of four members — [Krayzie
Bone](/wiki/Krayzie_Bone "Krayzie Bone"), [Layzie Bone](/wiki/Layzie_Bone
"Layzie Bone"), [Bizzy Bone](/wiki/Bizzy_Bone "Bizzy Bone"), and [Wish
Bone](/wiki/Wish_Bone "Wish Bone") (all except for [Flesh-n-Bone](/wiki/Flesh-
n-Bone "Flesh-n-Bone")) — and recorded an album entitled _[Faces of
Death](/wiki/Faces_of_Death_\(album\) "Faces of Death \(album\)")_ in the
studio of their then-mentor, Kermit Henderson (Krayzie Bone's older brother)
on his indie label Stoney Burke in 1993. Like so many aspiring rappers around
the country, they put in calls to executives at record companies, hoping to
find someone who would listen. In hopes of securing a record deal, the group
was given an audition over the phone, receiving an unfulfilled promise from
rapper [Eazy-E](/wiki/Eazy-E "Eazy-E") to call them back. Determined to reach
him, they scrounged together the money for [one-way bus
tickets](/wiki/Intercity_bus_service "Intercity bus service") to [Los
Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles"). They left for a three-day
[Greyhound](/wiki/Greyhound_bus "Greyhound bus") trek and spent four months on
the city streets, putting in frequent calls to find him. Nothing came of their
search except the news that Eazy-E was, in fact, on his way to Cleveland for a
show.

The quartet returned to Ohio, where Diego Blak (born Diego Hodge), a marketer
and promoter who had been co-executive producer of _Faces Of Death_ ,
introduced them to Eazy-E at a concert he promoted in Cleveland. There, on
November 2, 1993, they auditioned for Eazy in his dressing room; Krayzie
performed his verse of "Flow Motion" from the _Faces of Death_ album, and Eazy
was impressed.[11] B.O.N.E Enterpri$e then traveled back to Los Angeles after
the Cleveland show to seal the deal. At this point, Eazy renamed them Thugs-N-
Harmony, but as they wanted to keep the bone name, they made their name Bone
Thugs-N-Harmony. Eazy [signed](/wiki/Recording_contract "Recording contract")
the group (minus Flesh-n-Bone) to his label [Ruthless
Records](/wiki/Ruthless_Records "Ruthless Records").[1]

### 1994: _Creepin on ah Come Up_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bone_Thugs-n-
Harmony&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: 1994: Creepin on ah Come Up")]

Released in June 1994, the [EP](/wiki/Extended_play "Extended play") _[Creepin
on ah Come Up](/wiki/Creepin_on_ah_Come_Up "Creepin on ah Come Up")_ was Bone
Thugs-N-Harmony's debut with Ruthless. The album's subject matter was focused
almost entirely on [violent criminal activity](/wiki/Gangsta_rap "Gangsta
rap"). Peaking at #12 on the [_Billboard_ Top 200 Albums](/wiki/Billboard_200
"Billboard 200") chart and #2 on the [Top R&B/Hip-Hop
Albums](/wiki/Top_R%26B/Hip-Hop_Albums "Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums") chart,[12] it
included the hit singles "[Thuggish Ruggish Bone](/wiki/Thuggish_Ruggish_Bone
"Thuggish Ruggish Bone")" and "[Foe tha Love of $](/wiki/Foe_tha_Love_of_$
"Foe tha Love of $")", the second of which featured a verse by Eazy-E.
"Thuggish Ruggish Bone" peaked at #22 on the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") chart and #2 on the [Hot Rap
Tracks](/wiki/Hot_Rap_Tracks "Hot Rap Tracks") chart, and "Foe tha Love of $"
peaked at #41 on the Hot 100 and #4 on Rap Tracks.[13] After a slow start that
saw the album's success limited to [gangsta rap](/wiki/Gangsta_rap "Gangsta
rap") audiences, it broke through to the mainstream. The EP marked a major
change in style for the group, as they now fully embraced the
[G-funk](/wiki/G-funk "G-funk") common in [West Coast hip
hop](/wiki/West_Coast_hip_hop "West Coast hip hop") of the time. Beats were
supplied by [DJ Yella](/wiki/DJ_Yella "DJ Yella"), Rhythum D, and Kenny
McCloud, and it was the group's first collaboration with newcomer producer [DJ
U-Neek](/wiki/DJ_U-Neek "DJ U-Neek"), who would craft the group's signature
sound by producing the majority of their next two albums. For over a year,
Eazy-E nurtured their career, continuing to serve as their executive producer
and teaching them the business skills he had taught himself over the years.
The growing relationship was cut short, however, when Eazy-E died on March 26,
1995, from complications from [AIDS](/wiki/AIDS "AIDS"). Briefly, the young
rappers thought they had lost everything with the loss of their friend and
mentor. However, the group's potential was already apparent, and Ruthless
Records continued to support them.

### 1995–96: _E. 1999 Eternal_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bone_Thugs-n-
Harmony&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: 1995–96: E. 1999 Eternal")]

In 1995, the group's second album, _[E. 1999 Eternal](/wiki/E._1999_Eternal
"E. 1999 Eternal")_ , was released. It included the singles "[1st of tha
Month](/wiki/1st_of_tha_Month "1st of tha Month")", which peaked at #14 on the
Hot 100 and #4 on Hot Rap Tracks, and "[Tha Crossroads](/wiki/Tha_Crossroads
"Tha Crossroads")", which reached #1 on both the Hot 100 and Hot Rap Tracks
charts. The album generally saw positive reviews from critics as Bone had
diversified its content and musical style. Critics were particularly intrigued
by the album due to Bone Thugs-N-Harmony's ability to reduce the banality
associated with gangsta rap in their music at a time when the subgenre had
become exceedingly cliché.[14] A considerable portion of the album's concept
was built upon violent subject matter, yet they also incorporated deeper
themes, as its songs dealt with more [spirituality](/wiki/Spirituality
"Spirituality") and [occult](/wiki/Occult "Occult")
[mysticism](/wiki/Mysticism "Mysticism").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
album was produced by [DJ U-Neek](/wiki/DJ_U-Neek "DJ U-Neek") (with co-
production from Tony C. and Kenny McCloud). _E. 1999 Eternal_ also introduced
Bone's trademark tracks devoted entirely to the use of
[marijuana](/wiki/Marijuana "Marijuana"). The album name originated from one
of the street names of a corner (E. 99th street & St. Clair) that was a
familiar hangout to Bone members, as well as Eazy-E's album, _[Eternal
E](/wiki/Eternal_E "Eternal E")_. Naming it after Eazy-E's album was just
another way of showing respect and tribute to the rapper who had helped them
reach success. Also in 1995, Flesh-n-Bone would become the first member of the
group to release a debut album, entitled T.H.U.G.S, which was certified
[gold](/wiki/Gold_disc "Gold disc") by the [RIAA](/wiki/RIAA "RIAA"). In 1996,
due to their success, the Cleveland clan established their own label, [Mo
Thugs Records](/wiki/Mo_Thugs_Records "Mo Thugs Records"), and released the
_[Family Scriptures](/wiki/Family_Scriptures "Family Scriptures")_ compilation
album to introduce many of the Cleveland-based and other artists whom they
were developing. _E. 1999 Eternal_ is the group's most commercially successful
album; it has since been certified 5x [platinum](/wiki/Platinum_disc "Platinum
disc") by the RIAA.

There were plans for Bone Thugs-N-Harmony to collaborate with [West Coast
rapper](/wiki/West_Coast_rap "West Coast rap") [2Pac](/wiki/2Pac "2Pac") on a
studio album called _One Nation_. The project would bring together other hip
hop artists from all areas of the American map such as [Boot Camp
Clik](/wiki/Boot_Camp_Clik "Boot Camp Clik"),[15] [OutKast](/wiki/OutKast
"OutKast"), [Scarface](/wiki/Scarface_\(rapper\) "Scarface \(rapper\)"),
[E-40](/wiki/E-40 "E-40"), and more.[16] As 2Pac was unfortunately shot the
album never came into fruition.However, bootlegs of songs produced while Pac
was still alive have been distributed.

### 1997–2001: _The Art of War_ and
_BTNHResurrection_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bone_Thugs-n-
Harmony&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: 1997–2001: The Art of War and
BTNHResurrection")]

In 1997, the group released the [double-disc](/wiki/Double_album "Double
album") set _[The Art of War](/wiki/The_Art_of_War_\(Bone_Thugs-n-
Harmony_album\) "The Art of War \(Bone Thugs-n-Harmony album\)")_. The album
saw Bone further explore a wide variety of subjects and styles, with even more
focus on God and family and an overall more ambient, mellow sound. The group
still incorporated violent lyrics, however, with a large portion of the album
dedicated to what they labeled "clones" who claimed Bone had stolen their
quick-tongued rapping style and vice versa. The album had been rumored to be
titled "DNA Level C" which is Cleveland backwards.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
single "[Look into My Eyes](/wiki/Look_into_My_Eyes_\(Bone_Thugs-n-
Harmony_song\) "Look into My Eyes \(Bone Thugs-n-Harmony song\)")" appeared on
the soundtrack of the film _[Batman& Robin](/wiki/Batman_%26_Robin_\(film\)
"Batman & Robin \(film\)")_. It peaked at #4 on the Hot 100 and #2 on the Hot
Rap Tracks chart.[13] "[If I Could Teach The
World](/wiki/If_I_Could_Teach_The_World "If I Could Teach The World")", the
other single from _The Art of War_ , peaked at #27 on the Hot 100 and #3 on
the Hot Rap Tracks,[13] and won an [American Music
Award](/wiki/American_Music_Award "American Music Award"). The album also
included "Thug Luv" with [Tupac Shakur](/wiki/Tupac_Shakur "Tupac Shakur").
The group's promotional efforts were dampened by the absence of [Bizzy
Bone](/wiki/Bizzy_Bone "Bizzy Bone") from the album's videos and from large
portions of the ensuing tour and other public appearances. This absence
eventually fueled rumors of a break-up.

In 2000, Bone Thugs-N-Harmony released
_[BTNHResurrection](/wiki/BTNHResurrection "BTNHResurrection")_ , featuring
the single "[Resurrection (Paper, Paper)](/wiki/Resurrection_\(Paper,_Paper\)
"Resurrection \(Paper, Paper\)")", which peaked on the [Hot R&B/Hip-Hop
Songs](/wiki/Hot_R%26B/Hip-Hop_Songs "Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs") chart at
#52.[13] The album's first half featured a slew of hardcore and dark tracks,
with the second half being considerably more introspective and soft. Other
singles from the album, including "Can't Give it Up", failed to crack the
Billboard Hot 100, and the big-budget video for "Change the World" failed to
receive any rotation. This was their first group album to prominently feature
[Flesh-n-Bone](/wiki/Flesh-n-Bone "Flesh-n-Bone"), whose presence had been
limited on previous releases because he had never signed with the group's
label, Ruthless Records. Flesh was convicted for assault with a
[firearm](/wiki/Firearm "Firearm") and criminal possession of a weapon in June
2000.[17] Pleading guilty, Flesh was sentenced to 11 years in prison.[18]

The group again began having public disputes with Bizzy Bone. Bizzy Bone
abstained from promoting _BTNHResurrection_ because he felt that Ruthless
Records owed him money.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] He dropped a million-dollar lawsuit he had
filed against [Sony Music](/wiki/Sony_Music "Sony Music") and [Loud
Records](/wiki/Loud_Records "Loud Records") in exchange for a termination of
his Sony contract.[19] Three members of Bone Thugs-N-Harmony released solo
albums in 2001: Bizzy Bone with _[The
Gift](/wiki/The_Gift_\(Bizzy_Bone_album\) "The Gift \(Bizzy Bone album\)")_ ,
Layzie Bone (under the name L-Burna) with _[Thug by
Nature](/wiki/Thug_by_Nature "Thug by Nature")_ , and Krayzie Bone with _[Thug
on da Line](/wiki/Thug_on_da_Line "Thug on da Line")_.[20]

### 2002–06: _Thug World Order_ and _Thug
Stories_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bone_Thugs-n-Harmony&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: 2002–06: Thug World Order and Thug Stories")]

In 2002, the group released _[Thug World Order](/wiki/Thug_World_Order "Thug
World Order")_. This album, made up of what were described[_[by
whom?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")_] as overly-violent and political
songs, saw a drastic change in subject matter and tone for the group. The
lyrics were almost completely void of any violence, while a larger number of
tracks focused on the group itself. In contrast, several songs originally
intended to be included on the album that were leaked after its release
portrayed a much different album.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
album debuted at #12 on the _Billboard_ 200.[12] The first single released
from the album was "Get Up & Get It", featuring [3LW](/wiki/3LW "3LW"). The
second single, "Home", which featured [Phil Collins](/wiki/Phil_Collins "Phil
Collins") performing part of his song "[Take Me
Home](/wiki/Take_Me_Home_\(Phil_Collins_song\) "Take Me Home \(Phil Collins
song\)")", peaked at #33 on the [Rhythmic Top 40](/wiki/Rhythmic_Top_40
"Rhythmic Top 40"), impacting the charts in a number of countries, most
notably the United Kingdom.[13] Bizzy Bone was expelled from the group in
January 2003, leaving only 3 active members: Krayzie Bone, Layzie Bone, and
Wish Bone.[21] _Thug World Order_ was also Bone Thugs-N-Harmony's final album
with Ruthless Records; after their original contract with Ruthless had
expired, they decided they wanted to do their own thing.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

_[Thug Stories](/wiki/Thug_Stories "Thug Stories")_ , Bone Thugs-N-Harmony's
seventh album, was recorded on [Koch Records](/wiki/Koch_Records "Koch
Records") and released on September 19, 2006. It marked the first time Bone
Thugs had recorded as a trio since they released an internet-only
[EP](/wiki/Extended_play "Extended play") album called _Bone 4 Life_[22] in
September 2005. _Thug Stories_ featured a slightly more mature style, and the
group leaned more heavily towards its [harmonic](/wiki/Harmony "Harmony")
roots than its "[thug](/wiki/Gangsta_rap "Gangsta rap")" origins. The album
sold 38,000 in its first week and peaked at #25 on the [_Billboard_
200](/wiki/Billboard_200 "Billboard 200")[12] and #1 on the [Independent
Albums](/wiki/Independent_Albums "Independent Albums") chart.

### 2007: _Strength & Loyalty_ and
_T.H.U.G.S._[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bone_Thugs-n-
Harmony&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: 2007: Strength & Loyalty and
T.H.U.G.S.")]

Originally to be called _The Bone Thugs Story_ , _[Strength&
Loyalty](/wiki/Strength_%26_Loyalty "Strength & Loyalty")_ was released on May
8, 2007 on [Interscope Records](/wiki/Interscope_Records "Interscope Records")
imprint [Full Surface Records](/wiki/Full_Surface_Records "Full Surface
Records"). Being their first major album after an absence of nearly five
years, the album debuted at #2 on the _Billboard_ 200, and #1 on
[iTunes](/wiki/ITunes "ITunes") and the _Billboard_ [urban
music](/wiki/Top_R%26B/Hip-Hop_Albums "Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums") charts.[12]
The album contains guest appearances by [Mariah Carey](/wiki/Mariah_Carey
"Mariah Carey"), [The Game](/wiki/The_Game_\(rapper\) "The Game \(rapper\)"),
[will.i.am](/wiki/Will.i.am "Will.i.am"), [Akon](/wiki/Akon "Akon"),
[Twista](/wiki/Twista "Twista"), [Bow Wow](/wiki/Bow_Wow_\(rapper\) "Bow Wow
\(rapper\)"), [Yolanda Adams](/wiki/Yolanda_Adams "Yolanda Adams"), and
[Felecia](/wiki/Felecia_Lindsey-Howse "Felecia Lindsey-Howse"). Producers on
the album included [Swizz Beatz](/wiki/Swizz_Beatz "Swizz Beatz"),
[Akon](/wiki/Akon "Akon"), Pretty Boy & Bradd Young, [DJ Toomp](/wiki/DJ_Toomp
"DJ Toomp"), [Jermaine Dupri](/wiki/Jermaine_Dupri "Jermaine Dupri"),
[will.i.am](/wiki/Will.i.am "Will.i.am"), and others. The executive producer
of the album was [Swizz Beatz](/wiki/Swizz_Beatz "Swizz Beatz"). The first
single was "[I Tried](/wiki/I_Tried_\(Bone_Thugs-N-Harmony_song\) "I Tried
\(Bone Thugs-N-Harmony song\)")", which was their first top-10 hit in 10
years, peaking at number 6 on the U.S. [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100"). The second single was "[Lil
Love](/wiki/Lil_L.O.V.E. "Lil L.O.V.E.")", which failed to reach the success
of its predecessor. The album has been certified [gold](/wiki/Gold_disc "Gold
disc") by the RIAA.[23]

2007 also saw the release of the
semi-[autobiographical](/wiki/Autobiographical "Autobiographical") film _I
Tried_ , directed by [Rich Newey](/wiki/Rich_Newey "Rich Newey"), which
explored what might have happened to Bone Thugs-N-Harmony had they not gotten
their break with Eazy-E. Layzie, Krayzie, and Wish Bone starred in the film,
playing themselves.[24] Also in 2007, Bone Thugs-N-Harmony won the [American
Music Award](/wiki/American_Music_Award "American Music Award") for Favorite
Rap/Hip-Hop Band, Duo or Group.

_[T.H.U.G.S.](/wiki/T.H.U.G.S._\(Bone_Thugs-n-Harmony_album\) "T.H.U.G.S.
\(Bone Thugs-n-Harmony album\)")_ , an album featuring previously-unreleased,
largely [remixed](/wiki/Remix "Remix") Bone Thugs-N-Harmony songs that hadn't
made the final cut of the _[BTNHResurrection](/wiki/BTNHResurrection
"BTNHResurrection")_ and _[Thug World Order](/wiki/Thug_World_Order "Thug
World Order")_ albums, was released on November 13, 2007 by their former
record label, [Ruthless Records](/wiki/Ruthless_Records "Ruthless Records").
Although the album embodies old tracks, there are some notable changes: new
beats, [distorted](/wiki/Audio_distortion "Audio distortion") production,
voice manipulation, and new song titles. The sole single off the album was
"Young Thugs", which was accompanied by a newly filmed music video featuring
Krayzie, Layzie, Bizzy, and Wish.

In November 2007, Layzie Bone confirmed that he had completed the _[Bone
Brothers III](/wiki/Bone_Brothers_III "Bone Brothers III")_ album with Bizzy
Bone, spurring speculation about a full Bone reunion. In a video interview,
Krayzie Bone stated that they all wanted to reunite but that record label
issues might prevent an official reunion.[25] [Bizzy Bone](/wiki/Bizzy_Bone
"Bizzy Bone") had attended a Bone Thugs performance during that time, and he
and the three then-active members had a "good conversation".[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

After nearly a decade of incarceration, [Flesh-n-Bone](/wiki/Flesh-n-Bone
"Flesh-n-Bone") was released from prison on July 13, 2008. In an interview,
Bizzy confirmed his return, the group having reunited in time for Flesh's
release.[26]

### 2010–13: _Uni5: The World 's Enemy_ and _The Art of War: World War
III_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bone_Thugs-n-Harmony&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: 2010–13: Uni5: The World's Enemy and The Art of War: World War
III")]

Bone Thugs-N-Harmony's five members officially returned with their new album
_[Uni5: The World's Enemy](/wiki/Uni5:_The_World%27s_Enemy "Uni5: The World's
Enemy")_, released on May 4, 2010 by their own record label, [BTNH
Worldwide](/wiki/BTNH_Worldwide "BTNH Worldwide"), with distribution by
[Warner Bros.](/wiki/Warner_Music_Group "Warner Music Group") _Uni5_ also
marks the return of long-time Bone collaborator [DJ U-Neek](/wiki/DJ_U-Neek
"DJ U-Neek"), who was absent from 2007's _Strength & Loyalty_ but had produced
for the group throughout their career, including on hits "Thuggish Ruggish
Bone" and "Tha Crossroads". This studio effort leans toward radio-friendly
numbers and proper grown-man tracks, with the core four members offering life
lessons as Bizzy gives his Biblical perspective.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] They
released the singles "See Me Shine", featuring Jay Rush and [Lyfe
Jennings](/wiki/Lyfe_Jennings "Lyfe Jennings"), and "Rebirth", featuring
Thin-C, a member of the [Mo Thugs](/wiki/Mo_Thugs "Mo Thugs").[27] A third
single, "[Meet Me in the Sky](/wiki/Meet_Me_in_the_Sky "Meet Me in the Sky")",
was released on March 22.

Bone Thugs-N-Harmony announced on their blog over the summer of 2011 that they
were planning a new album for 2012.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] They
reiterated those plans in a November interview.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Throughout 2011, [Krayzie Bone](/wiki/Krayzie_Bone "Krayzie Bone"), [Bizzy
Bone](/wiki/Bizzy_Bone "Bizzy Bone"), and [Layzie Bone](/wiki/Layzie_Bone
"Layzie Bone") spoke about many new projects coming in 2012. Those projects
were to include an anniversary album featuring all 5 members; a Bizzy &
Krayzie duet album; and compilation albums of unreleased Bone Thugs-N-Harmony
material from the mid to late 90's and 2000's, prospectively titled _Lost
Archives Vol. 1_. The group put their differences aside to reunite and
belatedly mark their 20th anniversary at the [Rock the
Bells](/wiki/Rock_the_Bells "Rock the Bells") festival series of summer
2012.[28]

During the summer of 2012, West Coast rapper [Game](/wiki/Game_\(rapper\)
"Game \(rapper\)") sampled Bone Thugs-N-Harmony's "1st Of Tha Month" on his
new [posse cut](/wiki/Posse_cut "Posse cut")
"[Celebration](/wiki/Celebration_\(Game_song\) "Celebration \(Game song\)")",
with the legendary group's blessing. Game also posted a picture on his
[Twitter](/wiki/Twitter "Twitter") showing the word "bone" constructed out of
[cannabis](/wiki/Cannabis_\(drug\) "Cannabis \(drug\)").[29] He later
confirmed that he was working in the studio with Bone Thugs-N-Harmony on a
remix of "Celebration" for his album _[Jesus
Piece](/wiki/Jesus_Piece_\(album\) "Jesus Piece \(album\)")_.[30]

_The Art of War: World War III_ was officially announced by Bone Thugs-N-
Harmony in an interview with [The Source
(magazine)](/wiki/The_Source_\(magazine\) "The Source \(magazine\)") on March
25, 2013.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]. In early November 2013, [Krayzie
Bone](/wiki/Krayzie_Bone "Krayzie Bone") told [HipHopDX](/wiki/HipHopDX
"HipHopDX") that the _Art of War III_ album would feature only Layzie, Bizzy,
and Flesh-N-Bone, and that neither he nor Wish Bone had recorded any material
for that album. However, Krayzie and Wish both ended up appearing on the album
in the form of previously unreleased tracks that had been cut from _Uni5: The
World 's Enemy_.[31] _[The Art of War: World War
III](/wiki/The_Art_of_War:_World_War_III "The Art of War: World War III")_ was
released on December 10, 2013.

### 2014–present: New album, _New Waves_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bone_Thugs-
n-Harmony&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: 2014–present: New album, New
Waves")]

On July 15, 2014, it was announced that Bone Thugs-N-Harmony would release
their final album in 2015. There would be only a single copy released, to be
[auctioned](/wiki/Auction "Auction") off, with bidding starting at $1 million.
The group also announced they would be conducting a 20-country world tour
beginning in December 2014.[32] The following day, Krazyie Bone revealed that
the album would be titled _E. 1999 Legends_. He then told
_[XXL](/wiki/XXL_\(magazine\) "XXL \(magazine\)")_ that he had approached the
group about a reunion album in the middle of the previous year, and they had
begun recording it at the end of 2013. Krayzie estimated that Bone Thugs-N-
Harmony had probably recorded 75 to 100 songs since they began work on the
album, which was planned as a [double-disc project](/wiki/Double_album "Double
album"). The first disc was to contain Bone Thugs-N-Harmony content
exclusively, with no features, and would have 18–20 songs. The second disc was
planned to feature a large number of big-name guest appearances such as
[Mariah Carey](/wiki/Mariah_Carey "Mariah Carey"), [Kendrick
Lamar](/wiki/Kendrick_Lamar "Kendrick Lamar"), [Phil
Collins](/wiki/Phil_Collins "Phil Collins"), [Wiz Khalifa](/wiki/Wiz_Khalifa
"Wiz Khalifa"), [Drake](/wiki/Drake_\(rapper\) "Drake \(rapper\)"), [A$AP
Mob](/wiki/A$AP_Mob "A$AP Mob"), and [Linkin Park](/wiki/Linkin_Park "Linkin
Park"), along with beats from [Dr. Dre](/wiki/Dr._Dre "Dr. Dre") & [DJ
U-Neek](/wiki/DJ_U-Neek "DJ U-Neek"), who had each been tapped for the album.
[Damizza](/wiki/Damizza "Damizza") would be producing/overseeing the entire
_E. 1999 Legends_ album project, which was projected to be distributed through
Damizza's Baby Ree Records label.[33]

On February 14, 2015 — Valentine's Day — producer and long-time Bone
collaborator Damizza officially presented the single "More Than Thugs", slated
to appear on the _Damizza Presents_ album.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
group's vocal delivery on the song would be considered by
many[_[who?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")_] as vintage Bone Thugs-N-Harmony
vocal sound.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] As of late April 2015, the video for "More Than
Thugs" was in the editing stage and featured all 5 members. Flesh Bone and
Wish Bone were in the studio with Damizza in 2015 to complete the eight Bone
songs that were close to finished for the _E. 1999 Legends_ album. Under
direction from [A&R](/wiki/A%26R "A&R") team and long-time manager Steve Lobel
and agent Jamie Adler, they are also working on the remix of [Machine Gun
Kelly](/wiki/Machine_Gun_Kelly_\(rapper\) "Machine Gun Kelly \(rapper\)")'s
[Cleveland](/wiki/Cleveland "Cleveland") anthem single "Till I
Die".[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] In August 2015, Krayzie announced that the first bid of at least $1
million had been received for _E. 1999 Legends_.[34]

In 2017, Krayzie Bone and Bizzy Bone announced that they would be releasing
their long-awaited duet album together entitled _New Waves_ under the name
Bone Thugs. The album's lead single "Coming Home" featuring [Stephen
Marley](/wiki/Stephen_Marley_\(musician\) "Stephen Marley \(musician\)") was
released on March 24. Krayzie confirmed that the full Bone Thugs-n-Harmony
group was working on a new album, but said that they would no longer be
auctioning off the album's rights.[35]
